title: The Wage-Productivity Gap
subtitle: Hourly compensation vs. productivity growth (1948=100)
commonClaim: Wages stopped tracking productivity in 1971 when Nixon ended the gold standard.
actualTrend: The divergence began in the early 1970s but accelerated in the 1980s. Multiple factors — not just monetary policy — drove the gap, including globalization, declining unions, technological change, and policy choices.

dataSource.name: Economic Policy Institute (EPI), BLS data

annotations.description: China's accession to World Trade Organization accelerates offshoring

annotations.label: Financial crisis
annotations.description: Great Recession begins, wages stagnate further

causes.name: Globalization & trade competition
causes.description: Competition from lower-wage countries put downward pressure on wages, especially in manufacturing.

causes.name: Declining union membership
causes.description: Union membership fell from 35% in 1954 to 10% by 2023, reducing workers' bargaining power.

causes.name: Technology & automation
causes.description: Technology increased productivity but displaced middle-skill jobs, creating a 'hollowed out' labor market.

causes.name: Policy choices (tax, minimum wage)
causes.description: Top tax rate cuts, stagnant minimum wage, and deregulation shifted income toward capital owners.

causes.name: Measurement differences
causes.description: Some of the gap reflects using different price deflators for productivity vs. compensation.

skepticView.title: The gap is partly a measurement artifact
skepticView.summary: Using consistent deflators narrows the gap significantly. Total compensation (including benefits) has grown more than wages alone.
skepticView.interpretation: While a real divergence exists, the dramatic visuals often exaggerate it. The choice of deflator, the exclusion of benefits, and top-coding of survey data all inflate the apparent gap. The story is more nuanced than 'workers got nothing.'

neutralView.title: Multiple forces drove a real divergence
neutralView.summary: A genuine gap opened between productivity and typical worker compensation starting in the 1970s, driven by globalization, declining unions, technology, and policy choices.
neutralView.interpretation: The divergence is real but didn't have a single cause. It accelerated at different points: the 1970s oil shocks, 1980s deregulation, 2000s China shock. Attributing it solely to the end of the gold standard oversimplifies a complex economic transformation.

believerView.title: Abandoning the gold standard broke the link
believerView.summary: Once the dollar was decoupled from gold in 1971, monetary expansion allowed asset prices to surge while wages stagnated in real terms.
believerView.interpretation: The timing is clear: wages and productivity tracked closely until 1971, then diverged. Fiat money enabled credit expansion that disproportionately benefited asset holders, while inflation eroded real wages for workers.

subtitle: Median home price relative to median household income
commonClaim: Houses became unaffordable after 1971 because fiat money inflated asset prices.
actualTrend: Housing affordability deteriorated in waves — the late 1970s, mid-2000s, and post-2020 — driven by zoning restrictions, population shifts, interest rate changes, and speculation, not just monetary policy.

causes.name: Zoning & land use restrictions
causes.description: Local zoning laws restrict housing supply in high-demand areas, driving up prices. States like California and New York are especially constrained.

causes.name: Low interest rates & credit expansion
causes.description: Lower mortgage rates increase buying power, but push up prices. The 30-year mortgage itself is a government-backed subsidy to homeowners.

causes.name: Population growth in metro areas
causes.description: Urban population grew from 64% to 83% since 1950. More people competing for constrained housing supply in desirable metro areas.

causes.name: Housing as investment vehicle
causes.description: Tax policy, 1031 exchanges, and cultural attitudes made housing a primary investment, increasing demand beyond shelter needs.
causes.source: Joint Center for Housing Studies, Harvard

causes.name: Construction cost increases
causes.description: Labor shortages, material costs, and regulatory compliance increased the cost of building new housing.

skepticView.title: Housing costs vary wildly by location
skepticView.summary: National averages mask enormous regional variation. Housing in Houston or Raleigh is still affordable; the crisis is concentrated in supply-constrained cities.
skepticView.interpretation: If fiat currency were the main driver, housing would be equally unaffordable everywhere. Instead, the affordability crisis maps almost perfectly to local zoning restrictions. The cities that build enough housing have kept prices reasonable.

neutralView.title: A supply crisis amplified by cheap credit
neutralView.summary: Housing unaffordability stems primarily from insufficient supply in high-demand areas, amplified by low interest rates, tax incentives, and speculative buying.
neutralView.interpretation: The ratio has risen in waves tied to specific events: late-70s inflation, mid-2000s subprime bubble, post-2020 pandemic boom. Each wave had distinct causes. Monetary policy played a role but zoning restrictions are the structural foundation of the crisis.

believerView.title: Fiat money inflated housing into an asset class
believerView.summary: Once money could be created without gold backing, credit expansion made housing a speculative asset rather than shelter, permanently inflating prices relative to wages.
believerView.interpretation: The steady upward trend since 1971 speaks for itself. Each era of loose monetary policy — the late 70s, post-2001, post-2008 QE, post-2020 — produced a new surge in housing prices. Money creation flows into assets first, wages last.

causes.description: Top marginal rates fell from 91% (1960s) to 37% today. Capital gains preferentially taxed at lower rates. These directly increased after-tax income concentration.

causes.name: Financialization of the economy
causes.description: Finance sector profits grew from 10% to 30% of all corporate profits. Financial assets are concentrated among the wealthy.

causes.name: Winner-take-all markets
causes.description: Technology and globalization created markets where small advantages yield enormous rewards (tech, entertainment, sports, finance).

causes.name: Executive compensation growth

causes.name: Declining labor power

skepticView.title: The timing contradicts the gold standard theory
skepticView.summary: Inequality DECREASED from 1971 to 1979. The surge began with 1980s policy changes, a full decade after the gold standard ended.
skepticView.interpretation: This chart actually undermines the wtfhappenedin1971 narrative. If ending the gold standard caused inequality, you'd expect an immediate increase. Instead, the top 1% share hit its all-time LOW in 1978. The real inflection point was the 1980s tax and deregulation revolution.

neutralView.title: Policy, technology, and markets reshaped income distribution
neutralView.summary: The rise in top income share was driven by tax cuts, financialization, technology, and globalization, with monetary policy playing an indirect supporting role.
neutralView.interpretation: The data shows a clear regime change around 1980, not 1971. Multiple reinforcing factors — lower taxes on high incomes, financial deregulation, stock-based compensation, globalization — all pushed in the same direction. The gold standard ending was one of many institutional changes in this era.

believerView.title: Fiat money enabled the financialization that enriched the top 1%
believerView.summary: Without the gold standard constraint, credit creation fueled asset price inflation that disproportionately benefited the already wealthy.
believerView.interpretation: The gold standard didn't end in a vacuum — it enabled the credit expansion, financial deregulation, and asset price inflation that followed. The 1970s were a transition period; the effects became visible in the 1980s as the financial system fully adapted to fiat money.

title: US Trade Balance
subtitle: Exports minus imports as percentage of GDP
commonClaim: The US went from trade surplus to permanent deficit after abandoning the gold standard in 1971.
actualTrend: The trade deficit emerged in the mid-1970s and widened dramatically after 2000. The shift reflects the Triffin dilemma (reserve currency must run deficits), deindustrialization, and globalization — not simply the end of gold convertibility.

dataSource.name: Federal Reserve (FRED), Bureau of Economic Analysis

annotations.label: Nixon Shock
annotations.description: Dollar decoupled from gold, exchange rates begin floating

annotations.label: Plaza Accord
annotations.description: G5 nations agree to weaken the dollar to reduce US trade deficit

annotations.label: NAFTA
annotations.description: North American Free Trade Agreement takes effect

annotations.label: China joins WTO
annotations.description: China's WTO accession accelerates manufacturing offshoring

annotations.label: Peak deficit
annotations.description: Trade deficit reaches -5.5% of GDP, the widest in US history

causes.name: Triffin dilemma (reserve currency)
causes.description: As the world's reserve currency, the US must supply dollars globally, which requires running trade deficits. This is structural, not a policy failure.

causes.name: Globalization & offshoring
causes.description: US manufacturing shifted to lower-cost countries, especially China after its WTO accession in 2001. The 'China shock' alone eliminated 2-2.4 million US jobs.

causes.name: Strong dollar attracting imports
causes.description: Foreign demand for US assets (bonds, stocks) keeps the dollar strong, making imports cheap and exports expensive.

causes.name: Shift to service economy
causes.description: The US comparative advantage shifted from manufacturing to services (tech, finance, entertainment), which are harder to export.

causes.name: Energy imports (declining)
causes.description: Oil imports were a major component of the deficit for decades, though US shale production has reduced this significantly since 2010.

skepticView.title: Trade deficits reflect strength, not weakness
skepticView.summary: The US runs deficits because it's the world's most attractive destination for investment. Capital surpluses (inflows) are the mirror image of trade deficits.
skepticView.interpretation: Every dollar of trade deficit is matched by a dollar of foreign investment flowing into the US. The deficit means the world wants to invest here. Countries with trade surpluses (Japan since 1990, Germany) haven't necessarily had better economic outcomes for their citizens.

neutralView.title: Structural forces, not just monetary policy, drove the shift
neutralView.summary: The trade deficit reflects the Triffin dilemma, globalization, deindustrialization, and the shift to a service economy.
neutralView.interpretation: This is one of the stronger charts for the 1971 thesis — the timing is real. But the causes are multifactorial: reserve currency status, NAFTA, China's WTO entry, and comparative advantage shifts all played major roles. Other fiat-currency nations (Japan, Germany) run persistent surpluses, proving fiat money doesn't inherently cause deficits.

believerView.title: Fiat money broke the trade balance mechanism
believerView.summary: Under the gold standard, trade deficits were self-correcting: gold outflows contracted the money supply and corrected imbalances. Fiat money removed this discipline.
believerView.interpretation: The gold standard enforced balance of payments discipline. Without it, the US could import indefinitely by printing money. The structural deficit is a direct consequence of having a fiat reserve currency that the world must hold.

title: Federal Debt-to-GDP Ratio
subtitle: Federal debt held by the public as percentage of GDP
commonClaim: Government debt exploded after 1971 because there was no gold constraint on spending.
actualTrend: Debt-to-GDP actually FELL from 1945 to 1981, reaching a post-war low of ~25%. It then rose due to specific fiscal policy choices: Reagan-era tax cuts, war spending, recession responses, and COVID relief. The gold standard didn't prevent massive WWII debt.

dataSource.name: Federal Reserve (FRED), Treasury Department

annotations.description: Gold standard ends — but debt was at a post-war LOW

annotations.label: Reagan tax cuts

annotations.label: Financial crisis

annotations.label: COVID response
annotations.description: Pandemic spending pushes debt back to WWII levels

causes.name: Tax cuts without spending cuts
causes.description: The 1981, 2001, 2003, and 2017 tax cuts reduced revenue without commensurate spending reductions, creating structural deficits.

causes.name: War spending
causes.description: The wars in Afghanistan and Iraq cost an estimated $8 trillion including veterans' care and interest, adding significantly to the debt.

causes.name: Recession responses

causes.name: Interest on existing debt
causes.description: Interest payments now exceed $1 trillion annually, creating a compounding effect where debt begets more debt.

skepticView.title: The chart contradicts the 1971 narrative
skepticView.summary: Debt-to-GDP was falling through the 1970s and hit its post-war LOW around 1981. The rise correlates with Reagan-era tax cuts, not the end of the gold standard.
skepticView.interpretation: This is devastating for the gold standard theory. If removing the gold constraint caused debt to explode, why did debt fall for a decade after 1971? And why did the gold standard not prevent the US from accumulating 106% debt-to-GDP during WWII? The data shows fiscal policy choices, not monetary system structure, drive debt levels.

neutralView.title: Fiscal policy choices, not monetary structure, drive debt
neutralView.summary: Debt growth correlates with specific decisions: tax cuts, wars, recession spending, and healthcare costs. The gold standard removal made deficit spending easier but didn't cause it.
neutralView.interpretation: The fiat system did remove one constraint on borrowing — governments no longer needed gold reserves to back currency. But the Clinton administration achieved surpluses under fiat money, proving the system doesn't mandate deficits. Each debt increase traces to identifiable policy decisions.

believerView.title: Removing gold discipline enabled permanent deficits
believerView.summary: Without the gold standard forcing fiscal discipline, politicians could deficit-spend without immediate consequences, leading to ever-growing debt.
believerView.interpretation: The gold standard was a constraint on government. Once removed, the temptation to spend beyond means became irresistible. Even if the timing wasn't instant, the removal of discipline made the current debt trajectory possible. The post-2008 explosion of debt would have been impossible under gold convertibility.

title: US Incarceration Rate
subtitle: State and federal prisoners per 100,000 population
commonClaim: Incarceration exploded after 1971 as economic conditions deteriorated.
actualTrend: The incarceration rate was stable from the 1920s to early 1970s, then quadrupled from 1973 to 2009. The cause was not economic distress but the War on Drugs (declared by Nixon in 1971), mandatory minimum sentencing, and the 1994 crime bill.

dataSource.name: Bureau of Justice Statistics, The Sentencing Project

causes.name: War on Drugs policies
causes.description: Drug offenses account for nearly half of federal prisoners. Harsh penalties for possession (not just trafficking) filled prisons with nonviolent offenders.

causes.name: Mandatory minimum sentencing
causes.description: Mandatory minimums removed judicial discretion, resulting in disproportionately long sentences. The crack-cocaine disparity (100:1 until 2010) was especially devastating.

causes.name: Three-strikes laws
causes.description: 28 states adopted three-strikes laws mandating life sentences for third felonies, regardless of severity.

causes.name: Racial disparities in enforcement
causes.description: Black Americans are incarcerated at 5x the rate of whites. Drug use rates are similar across races, but arrest and sentencing rates are not.

causes.name: Prison-industrial complex
causes.description: Private prisons, prison labor, and lobbying by corrections unions created financial incentives for incarceration.

skepticView.title: This has nothing to do with monetary policy
skepticView.summary: The War on Drugs, mandatory minimums, and three-strikes laws are the documented, unambiguous causes. The timing with 1971 is coincidental — Nixon declared the drug war that same year.
skepticView.interpretation: This chart is perhaps the most misleading inclusion on wtfhappenedin1971.com. Mass incarceration is a criminal justice policy story with clear legislative roots. Other fiat-currency nations (Canada, UK, Germany) don't have remotely similar incarceration rates, proving this is a US policy choice, not a monetary system outcome.

neutralView.title: Criminal justice policy, not economics, drove mass incarceration
neutralView.summary: The quadrupling of incarceration was caused by the War on Drugs, mandatory minimums, and tough-on-crime legislation — policies with clear legislative histories.
neutralView.interpretation: The 1971 timing is coincidental — Nixon happened to declare the War on Drugs the same year he ended gold convertibility. The incarceration surge came from specific legislation: Rockefeller laws (1973), Anti-Drug Abuse Act (1986), Crime Bill (1994). Economic stress may have contributed to support for tough-on-crime politics, but the direct cause is policy.

believerView.title: Economic deterioration after 1971 drove crime and incarceration
believerView.summary: As wages stagnated and inequality grew after 1971, economic desperation increased crime, leading to a political backlash that produced mass incarceration.
believerView.interpretation: While the direct cause is policy, the question is why those policies were adopted. Economic stress from the 1970s stagflation, deindustrialization, and wage stagnation may have created conditions where crime rose and voters demanded harsh responses. The monetary system shift was an upstream cause.

subtitle: Divorces per 1,000 population
commonClaim: Divorce rates surged after 1971 as economic stress destroyed families.
actualTrend: Divorce rates rose from the mid-1960s, peaked in 1981, and have declined steadily since. The surge was driven by no-fault divorce laws (starting 1969), women's economic independence, and changing social norms — not monetary policy.

causes.name: No-fault divorce laws
causes.description: Before 1969, courts could deny divorce without proof of fault (adultery, abuse). No-fault laws made divorce accessible. The surge tracks perfectly with state-by-state adoption.

causes.name: Women's economic independence
causes.description: Women's workforce participation rose from 38% (1960) to 58% (1990). Financial independence made leaving unhappy marriages possible.

causes.name: Changing social norms

causes.name: Contraception access

causes.name: Later marriage age

skepticView.title: No-fault divorce laws are the obvious explanation
skepticView.summary: The divorce surge began in 1969 (two years before the gold standard ended) and maps precisely to state-by-state adoption of no-fault divorce laws.
skepticView.interpretation: The implication that couples divorced because of 'bitter arguments on the convertibility of the dollar to gold' is absurd. No-fault divorce laws removed legal barriers. Women's economic independence made leaving bad marriages possible. The rate has declined since 1981 despite remaining on fiat money.

neutralView.title: Legal reform and social change, not monetary policy
neutralView.summary: Divorce rose due to no-fault laws, women's workforce entry, and changing social attitudes. The timing with 1971 is coincidental.
neutralView.interpretation: The divorce rate was already surging by 1969, peaked in 1981, and has declined steadily since. This is a story about women's liberation, legal reform, and cultural change. Economic stress may have contributed marginally, but the documented causes are non-monetary.

believerView.title: Economic stress from monetary debasement strained families
believerView.summary: Stagnating wages, inflation, and the need for dual incomes after 1971 created economic pressure that contributed to marital instability.
believerView.interpretation: While no-fault divorce laws were the proximate cause, the question is why they were adopted and why so many couples used them. Economic stress from 1970s stagflation — itself caused by monetary policy changes — may have increased marital strain and made divorce more common.

causes.description: Credit cards, auto loans, and buy-now-pay-later made consumption possible without saving first. US credit card debt exceeds $1 trillion.

skepticView.title: Credit access and consumer finance, not inflation
skepticView.summary: The savings decline tracks with credit card deregulation, mortgage innovation, and consumer finance expansion. Americans didn't stop saving — they started borrowing.
skepticView.interpretation: The savings rate was at its PEAK in 1971-73, contradicting the narrative that the gold standard's end immediately harmed savers. The decline came as financial innovation made consumption easier. Also, home equity and 401(k)s aren't captured in this metric, so actual wealth accumulation is understated.

neutralView.title: Multiple forces reduced saving — credit, wealth effects, and culture
neutralView.summary: The savings rate decline reflects credit access, perceived wealth from assets, the pension-to-401(k) shift, and stagnating wages — with monetary policy as a contributing factor.
neutralView.interpretation: There's a genuine connection between easy money and the savings decline: low interest rates make saving less rewarding and borrowing cheaper. But the decline was gradual and driven by identifiable non-monetary factors. The COVID savings spike showed Americans can save when conditions warrant it.

believerView.title: Inflation made saving irrational
believerView.summary: Under fiat money, inflation erodes the value of savings. Rational actors responded by spending and borrowing rather than saving depreciating dollars.
believerView.interpretation: When money loses purchasing power every year, saving becomes a losing proposition. The gold standard rewarded savers with stable purchasing power. Fiat money punishes savers and rewards borrowers, fundamentally changing economic behavior and encouraging a debt-driven consumption model.

actualTrend: Moderate, predictable inflation (averaging 2-3%) has been a feature of fiat currency systems since the 1980s. The high-volatility inflation of the 1970s was caused by oil shocks, not just monetary policy. Under the gold standard, deflationary spirals caused devastating depressions.

causes.name: Cumulative compounding is mathematical certainty
causes.description: Even at the Fed's target of 2%, prices double every 36 years. This chart simply shows that 2% annual inflation compounds over a century — it doesn't show instability.

causes.name: 1970s oil shocks (supply-side inflation)
causes.description: The 1973 OPEC embargo and 1979 Iranian Revolution caused oil prices to quadruple, driving the high inflation of the 1970s. This was supply-driven, not purely monetary.

causes.name: Fiat money enables monetary expansion
causes.description: Without the gold constraint, central banks can expand the money supply. This enables inflation, but also provides tools to fight recessions.

causes.name: Post-1980 inflation targeting
causes.description: Since Volcker, the Fed has maintained inflation near 2%. The 'Great Moderation' (1983-2007) showed fiat money can deliver price stability.
causes.source: Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis

causes.name: Gold standard had deflation crises
causes.description: The gold standard produced devastating deflationary episodes: 1873-1896 (Long Depression), 1929-1933 (Great Depression). Deflation is arguably worse than moderate inflation.

skepticView.title: This chart just shows that inflation exists
skepticView.summary: Cumulative inflation over 110 years looks dramatic on any chart. At a 2% target rate, this is exactly what you'd expect — and it's preferable to gold-standard deflation.
skepticView.interpretation: The chart is mathematically trivial: compound 2-3% over a century and you get a big number. The gold standard produced price stability on average, but with violent swings: 100% inflation during WWI, then 25% deflation during the Depression. Modern fiat money with inflation targeting has delivered far more predictable prices.

neutralView.title: Inflation is a feature, not a bug — but it must be managed
neutralView.summary: Moderate inflation is an intentional choice by central banks. The 1970s showed what happens when inflation is mismanaged; the post-1982 era showed it can be tamed.
neutralView.interpretation: The fiat system does produce continuous inflation — that's by design. The key question is rate and predictability. Since 1983, inflation has averaged ~2.5% — stable and predictable. The gold standard's price stability came with devastating deflationary crises and limited crisis-response tools.

believerView.title: The dollar has lost 98% of its purchasing power since 1913
believerView.summary: What cost $1 in 1913 costs over $30 today. The gold standard maintained purchasing power; fiat money systematically destroys it.
believerView.interpretation: The cumulative destruction of purchasing power is undeniable. A gold-denominated dollar held its value over centuries. The fiat dollar loses value every year. This is a hidden tax on savers and workers whose wages don't keep up with rising prices. The acceleration after 1971 is visible in the chart's exponential curve.

skepticView.title: The Gini was flat through the 1970s — the timing is wrong
skepticView.summary: Inequality was essentially unchanged from 1967 to 1980. The increase began in the 1980s with Reagan-era policy changes, not 1971.
skepticView.interpretation: Like the top 1% income share, the Gini contradicts the 1971 narrative. If the gold standard's end caused inequality, you'd see an immediate rise. Instead, the Gini was flat for a decade. The inflection came with 1980s deregulation, tax cuts, and globalization.

neutralView.title: Structural economic changes, not monetary policy, drove inequality
neutralView.summary: Rising inequality reflects declining unions, technological change, globalization, and tax policy — multiple forces that accelerated in the 1980s, not 1971.
neutralView.interpretation: The Gini measures a broad trend driven by labor market structure, education policy, trade, and taxation. Monetary policy affects inequality indirectly (through asset prices and interest rates), but the direct drivers are non-monetary. Other fiat-currency nations (Scandinavia, Japan) have much lower Gini coefficients.

believerView.title: Fiat money amplified inequality through asset inflation
believerView.summary: Credit expansion under fiat money inflated asset prices (stocks, housing) that are disproportionately owned by the wealthy, widening the gap.
believerView.interpretation: While the Gini didn't jump immediately in 1971, the removal of the gold constraint enabled the credit expansion and financialization that followed. The 1980s deregulation was only possible because the monetary system had already been unshackled. Asset inflation is the mechanism through which fiat money increases inequality.

commonClaim: Families needed two incomes after 1971 because one wage could no longer support a household.
actualTrend: Women's workforce participation surged due to the women's liberation movement, birth control availability, education access, and changing social norms. The trend began before 1971 and represents cultural progress as much as economic pressure.

causes.description: The feminist movement transformed social expectations. Women increasingly sought careers as fulfillment, not just economic necessity.

causes.name: Birth control & reproductive autonomy
causes.description: The Pill (1960), Griswold v. Connecticut (1965), and Roe v. Wade (1973) gave women control over timing of childbirth, enabling career investment.

skepticView.title: This is a women's rights story, not a monetary policy story
skepticView.summary: The rise of dual-income households began in the 1960s — before 1971 — and tracks with contraception, education access, and legal equality.
skepticView.interpretation: Framing women's workforce entry as a sign of economic distress erases the agency and achievement of the women's movement. The trend began with the Pill (1960), accelerated with the Civil Rights Act (1964) and Title IX (1972). The plateau since 2000 suggests a natural equilibrium, not ongoing desperation.

neutralView.title: Both opportunity and necessity drove the shift
neutralView.summary: Women entered the workforce due to expanded rights and opportunities, but rising costs also made dual incomes increasingly important.
neutralView.interpretation: The truth includes both narratives. Women's liberation was the primary driver — the trend started well before 1971. But economic pressure became a contributing factor, especially as housing and education costs rose. Elizabeth Warren's 'Two-Income Trap' argues that dual incomes actually increased competition for housing and schools, paradoxically making families more vulnerable.

believerView.title: Inflation forced families to need two incomes
believerView.summary: As real wages stagnated after 1971, families needed a second income to maintain the standard of living previously achievable on one salary.
believerView.interpretation: The timing fits: one income supported a family through the 1950s-60s. After 1971, inflation and wage stagnation made single-earner households increasingly unviable. Women's entry into the workforce was partly driven by economic necessity, not just choice. The cultural factors were real but the economic push was decisive.

actualTrend: Labor's share was relatively stable at ~64% from 1947 through 2000, then fell sharply to ~57% after 2000. The timing points to the 'China shock,' automation, and corporate concentration — not the 1971 gold standard change.

causes.description: China's WTO accession in 2001 accelerated offshoring of manufacturing. The labor share decline maps almost perfectly to the China shock timeline.

causes.name: Automation & AI
causes.description: Capital-intensive production (robots, software, AI) substitutes for labor, allowing output to grow without proportional wage increases.

causes.name: Corporate market concentration

causes.name: Declining worker bargaining power

causes.name: Rising depreciation costs

skepticView.title: Labor share was stable for 30 years after 1971
skepticView.summary: The decline began around 2000, not 1971. It correlates with China's WTO entry and the rise of superstar tech firms, not the gold standard.
skepticView.interpretation: This chart strongly contradicts the 1971 thesis. Labor share was remarkably stable from 1947 to 2000 — spanning both the gold standard and fiat eras. The sharp decline after 2000 points to globalization and technology, not monetary policy.

neutralView.title: Globalization, technology, and market power reshaped income distribution
neutralView.summary: The labor share decline is a post-2000 phenomenon driven by trade competition, automation, and corporate concentration.
neutralView.interpretation: This is one of the most important economic trends of the 21st century, but its timing exonerates monetary policy. The causes are structural: industries that can offshore or automate have seen their labor shares fall, while 'superstar firms' with high profits and few workers have pulled the aggregate down.

believerView.title: Fiat money enabled the capital accumulation that displaced labor
believerView.summary: Easy credit and asset inflation under fiat money enabled the massive capital investment (tech, automation) that substituted for labor.
believerView.interpretation: While the decline accelerated after 2000, the conditions were set by decades of fiat-money-enabled capital accumulation. Cheap credit funded the tech investments and corporate acquisitions that ultimately displaced workers. The gold standard would have constrained the capital accumulation that enabled this shift.

skepticView.title: This is a political science story, not an economics story
skepticView.summary: Polarization maps to specific political events: civil rights realignment, Gingrich revolution, media fragmentation. Monetary policy has nothing to do with it.

The drivers are well-documented: party sorting after the Civil Rights Act, the Fairness Doctrine repeal, gerrymandering, and social media. Other fiat-currency democracies (Canada, Germany) are far less polarized.

neutralView.title: Political structural changes, with economic stress as a contributing factor
neutralView.summary: Polarization is primarily driven by party realignment, media changes, and institutional incentives, with economic inequality providing fertile ground.
neutralView.interpretation: Economic anxiety can fuel political extremism, and rising inequality may have contributed to polarization. But the causal chain runs through specific political mechanisms (gerrymandering, media, campaign finance), not monetary policy. Countries with similar fiat systems but different political structures show different polarization patterns.

believerView.title: Economic deterioration after 1971 fueled political division
believerView.summary: Stagnating wages, rising inequality, and declining living standards created the economic anxiety that politicians exploited for partisan gain.
believerView.interpretation: While the direct causes of polarization are political, the underlying conditions were economic. The middle class was hollowed out after 1971 — real wages stagnated, inequality rose, and economic mobility declined. This created the anger and frustration that demagogues channeled into partisan warfare.

By 1971, the decline was nearly complete. The gold standard is irrelevant — this is a demographic transition driven by reproductive technology and women's rights.

neutralView.title: Reproductive technology and social change, not monetary policy
neutralView.summary: The fertility decline is a global phenomenon occurring across all monetary systems, driven by contraception, education, and urbanization.
neutralView.interpretation: Every developed country has experienced this transition — the 'demographic transition' is one of the most studied phenomena in social science. Countries with gold-backed currencies, fiat currencies, and everything in between all show declining fertility as women gain education and reproductive autonomy.

believerView.title: Economic insecurity made families unaffordable
believerView.summary: While contraception enabled the decline, economic factors — stagnating wages, housing costs, student debt — made young people unable or unwilling to have children.
believerView.interpretation: The post-2007 decline is harder to explain with reproductive technology alone. Young adults increasingly cite economic reasons for delaying or forgoing children: housing costs, student debt, childcare expenses, job instability. The economic deterioration that began after 1971 created conditions where family formation became financially prohibitive.

actualTrend: Real median household income roughly doubled from 1950 to 2000, but growth slowed significantly after 2000. causes.name: Declining union membership

causes.name: Household composition changes

skepticView.title: Income growth continued well after 1971
skepticView.summary: Real median income grew substantially through the 1990s and hit new records in 2019 and 2023. The slowdown correlates with specific economic shocks, not the end of the gold standard.
skepticView.interpretation: If the gold standard change caused income stagnation, why did incomes grow robustly for 30 more years? The real slowdown came after 2000, driven by the China shock, two recessions, and structural shifts in the labor market. Also, total compensation including benefits has grown more than wages alone.

neutralView.title: Growth slowed but didn't stop
neutralView.summary: Real median household income has grown more slowly since the 1970s, driven by globalization, technology, and labor market changes, with monetary policy playing an indirect role.
neutralView.interpretation: The data shows genuine slowdown in median income growth, but the timing doesn't cleanly match 1971. The 1970s saw solid income growth despite high inflation. The real deceleration came in the 2000s. Multiple factors converged to reduce the middle class's share of economic gains.

believerView.title: Fiat money eroded real purchasing power
believerView.summary: While nominal incomes rose, persistent inflation meant real gains were far smaller than they appear. Workers had to run faster just to stay in place.
believerView.interpretation: The pre-1971 era saw rapid real income growth because the gold standard kept prices stable. After 1971, inflation ate into nominal wage gains, and the government's CPI measurements understate true inflation by changing the basket of goods over time.

neutralView.title: Structural incentives, demographics, and technology drive healthcare inflation
neutralView.summary: Healthcare costs rose due to third-party payment removing price discipline, administrative waste, drug monopolies, and an aging population demanding more care.

believerView.title: Fiat money enabled unlimited government healthcare spending
believerView.summary: Without gold standard constraints, government could fund Medicare and Medicaid expansion through money creation, inflating healthcare prices far beyond what a sound-money system would allow.
believerView.interpretation: Government healthcare spending went from near-zero to $2 trillion annually because fiat money removed the fiscal constraint. This demand-side explosion, funded by money printing, is the primary driver of healthcare price inflation.

neutralView.title: State disinvestment and federal loan expansion created a cost spiral

believerView.title: Unlimited fiat credit inflated education into a speculative bubble
believerView.summary: Without gold standard constraints, the government could extend unlimited student credit, inflating tuition just as easy money inflated housing prices.
believerView.interpretation: Student loan debt now exceeds $1.7 trillion — a sum only possible in a fiat system. The government created money to lend to students, who bid up tuition prices, creating a debt trap that a gold standard would have prevented by constraining credit creation.

neutralView.title: Compensation structure, governance, and policy drove the gap

The shift to stock options in the 1990s created a feedback loop: rising markets increased CEO pay, which went into stocks, pushing markets higher.

believerView.title: Asset inflation from fiat money disproportionately enriched executives
believerView.summary: Fiat money enabled the credit expansion and asset price inflation that made stock-based CEO compensation so lucrative, while workers' wages stagnated in real terms.
believerView.interpretation: The mechanism is clear: fiat money creation flows into financial assets first (Cantillon effect). CEOs, paid largely in stock, benefited directly from asset inflation. Workers, paid in wages, saw their purchasing power eroded. The gold standard would have constrained the asset inflation that enriched executives.

The real challenge is affordability in specific metros, driven by zoning restrictions that have nothing to do with monetary systems.

neutralView.title: Affordability, debt, and supply constraints shape homeownership
neutralView.summary: Homeownership peaked and declined due to housing bubble aftermath, rising prices, student debt, and supply constraints — with low interest rates playing a dual role of enabling both access and price inflation.

But they also inflated home prices, eventually making the down payment barrier insurmountable for many. The net effect has been a slight decline from the unsustainable 2004 peak.

believerView.title: Fiat money turned housing from shelter into a speculative asset
believerView.summary: Easy money and credit expansion inflated home prices far beyond what wages could support, making homeownership dependent on ever-looser credit rather than genuine affordability.
believerView.interpretation: The 2004 peak was a mirage — it was achieved through subprime lending that proved unsustainable. True affordable homeownership (where homes cost 2x income) died in the 1970s. What replaced it was a debt-dependent system where homeownership requires 30-year mortgages and dual incomes.

commonClaim: The minimum wage lost its value after 1971 when inflation eroded purchasing power.
actualTrend: The real minimum wage peaked in 1968 at $13.28 (in 2023 dollars) and has declined 46% since then. The cause is not inflation alone — it is Congress's repeated failure to raise the nominal minimum wage. From 2009 to 2024, the $7.25 minimum was not adjusted at all, the longest freeze in its history.

skepticView.summary: The minimum wage decline is caused by Congress not raising it, not by inflation per se. If the minimum wage were indexed to inflation (as many countries do), the problem wouldn't exist.
skepticView.interpretation: Australia, France, and the UK all have fiat currencies and minimum wages that auto-adjust for inflation, maintaining their real value. The US decline is a choice — a policy failure, not a structural feature of fiat money.

neutralView.title: Congressional inaction, amplified by inflation, eroded the minimum wage
neutralView.summary: The real minimum wage has fallen because it is not indexed to inflation and Congress has failed to raise it regularly. Both the lack of indexing and the inflation that erodes value are contributing factors.
neutralView.interpretation: If the US had stayed on the gold standard, inflation would have been lower, partially preserving the minimum wage's value. But gold standard or not, the fundamental problem is that the minimum wage requires an act of Congress to change, making it vulnerable to political gridlock.

believerView.title: Inflation from fiat money destroyed the minimum wage
believerView.summary: Under the gold standard, the minimum wage held its value naturally. Fiat money's persistent inflation is the engine that eroded purchasing power, making the minimum wage worth 46% less than its 1968 peak.
believerView.interpretation: The gold standard era saw the minimum wage's purchasing power steadily rise because prices were relatively stable. After 1971, every year without a legislative increase meant a real pay cut. The system was designed for price stability — fiat money broke that assumption and broke the minimum wage with it.

neutralView.title: Financial asset growth has genuinely outpaced wage growth
neutralView.summary: The divergence is real and reflects monetary policy, globalization, and the shift from labor to capital income. But the chart overstates the divide because stocks benefit from global earnings.

Monetary policy since 2008 especially has inflated financial assets while doing little for wages. The result is a wealth divide between asset owners and wage earners that both monetary and fiscal policy could address.

believerView.title: Fiat money created two economies — one for asset owners, one for workers
believerView.summary: The Cantillon effect in action: new money enters through financial markets first, inflating asset prices long before it reaches workers' wages.
believerView.interpretation: Under the gold standard, stock prices and wages tracked much more closely because money supply growth was constrained. After 1971, the Fed could create unlimited money, which systematically flowed into financial assets first. This is the purest expression of how fiat money creates inequality.

neutralView.title: Multiple forces reduced saving
neutralView.summary: The savings decline reflects credit access, perceived wealth from assets, the pension-to-401(k) shift, and stagnating wages. Monetary policy played a supporting role through low rates.
neutralView.interpretation: Low interest rates from fiat-money policy did make saving less rewarding and borrowing cheaper. But the decline was gradual and driven by many non-monetary factors. The COVID savings spike proved Americans can save when conditions warrant it.

believerView.title: Inflation from fiat money made saving irrational
believerView.summary: Under fiat money, persistent inflation erodes savings' value. Rational actors responded by spending and borrowing rather than saving in a depreciating currency.
believerView.interpretation: When money loses purchasing power every year, saving becomes a losing strategy. The gold standard rewarded savers with stable purchasing power. Fiat money punishes savers and rewards borrowers, fundamentally reshaping economic behavior toward debt-driven consumption.

actualTrend: Union membership peaked at ~35% in the mid-1950s and fell to 10% by 2023. Middle class income share fell from 62% in 1970 to 42% in 2020. The correlation is strong and well-documented. The causes are policy choices: Taft-Hartley Act, right-to-work laws, NLRB weakening, and employer anti-union tactics.

skepticView.summary: Anti-union legislation, employer opposition, and globalization — not monetary policy — drove union decline. Countries with fiat currencies (Scandinavia) maintain 70%+ union rates.
skepticView.interpretation: Nordic countries have fiat currencies and union rates above 65%. The US decline tracks with specific anti-union policies: Taft-Hartley, PATCO, right-to-work expansions. The correlation between union decline and middle-class erosion is one of the strongest in labor economics.

neutralView.title: Union decline and middle class erosion share common causes
neutralView.summary: Both trends were driven by globalization, deindustrialization, policy choices, and technological change. The correlation between them is well-established and likely partly causal.

believerView.title: Economic instability from fiat money undermined labor power
believerView.summary: The inflationary, boom-bust cycle created by fiat money weakened unions by creating recessions that enabled union-busting and by eroding the stable manufacturing economy where unions thrived.
believerView.interpretation: The gold standard era was the golden age of unions because it provided economic stability. Fiat money's boom-bust cycles gave employers leverage during downturns to break unions. The 1970s stagflation and early 1980s recession were particularly devastating for organized labor.

The US actually still has the second-largest manufacturing output in the world. The issue is automation, not monetary policy.

neutralView.title: Automation, trade, and economic evolution drove manufacturing decline
neutralView.summary: Manufacturing employment decline reflects automation, globalization (especially the China shock), and the natural transition of wealthy economies toward services.
neutralView.interpretation: The decline was gradual from 1953-2000, then accelerated sharply with China's WTO entry. Monetary policy played a role through exchange rates, but the fundamental forces were technological change and comparative advantage. Notably, US manufacturing output has increased even as employment fell.

believerView.title: The devalued dollar made offshoring inevitable
believerView.summary: Ending gold convertibility devalued the dollar, making foreign labor artificially cheap and American manufacturing uncompetitive, accelerating the offshoring of American jobs.
believerView.interpretation: Under the gold standard, trade was balanced and manufacturing was the backbone of the economy. The floating exchange rate and trade deficits that followed 1971 enabled the hollowing out of American industry. The human cost — devastated factory towns, opioid epidemics, 'deaths of despair' — flows directly from this decision.

believerView.title: Fiat money's boom-bust cycles killed community banks

believerView.interpretation: Under the gold standard, banking was more stable and local. Fiat money enabled the credit expansion that caused the S&L crisis, 2008 crash, and other events that destroyed small banks. Each crisis made surviving big banks bigger and more powerful, a consolidation cycle only possible in a fiat system.

Other fiat-currency nations (Japan, Australia, Spain) have life expectancies of 83-84 years. The US lag is about healthcare system design, drug policy, and public health — not monetary policy.

neutralView.title: Specific health crises, not economic structure, drive the recent decline
neutralView.summary: Life expectancy gains continued for decades after 1971. The post-2014 decline is driven by the opioid epidemic, obesity, healthcare access gaps, and COVID-19.
neutralView.interpretation: There is a plausible indirect connection: economic distress in deindustrialized communities contributed to 'deaths of despair.' But the direct causes are well-documented: Purdue Pharma's marketing of OxyContin, inadequate mental health infrastructure, food system failures driving obesity, and pandemic unpreparedness.

believerView.title: Economic deterioration after 1971 eventually killed Americans
believerView.summary: The stagnation of wages, loss of manufacturing jobs, and erosion of community economic stability created the conditions for 'deaths of despair' — opioids, suicide, and alcoholism.
believerView.interpretation: The decline in life expectancy is concentrated in the same communities devastated by deindustrialization: Appalachia, the Rust Belt, rural America. These are the human casualties of the economic transformation that began in 1971. The opioid epidemic didn't happen in a vacuum — it happened in communities stripped of economic hope.

title: Hours Worked to Buy a Home
subtitle: Median home price divided by median hourly wage (total hours needed)
commonClaim: Workers must work far more hours to afford a home than before 1971.
actualTrend: The number of hours a median worker must work to buy a median home has increased from ~5,700 hours in 1960 to ~15,700 hours in 2023. This nearly tripled, with the sharpest increases coming in the 2000s housing bubble and the post-2020 surge. The divergence reflects both rising home prices and stagnating real wages.

causes.name: Stagnating median wages
causes.description: Median hourly wages grew only ~15% in real terms from 1970-2023, while home prices tripled. The numerator grows faster than the denominator.

causes.name: Low interest rates inflating prices
causes.description: Low mortgage rates increased buying power, but pushed up prices as more money chased limited housing. The 2020-2021 near-zero rates sent prices to records.

causes.name: Investor & institutional buying
causes.description: Institutional investors, REITs, and foreign buyers increased demand for housing as an investment asset, competing with first-time homebuyers.

skepticView.title: Zoning and supply constraints, not fiat money, made housing expensive
skepticView.summary: Housing affordability varies enormously by location. Cities that allow construction (Houston, Raleigh) remain affordable. Supply-constrained cities (SF, NYC) are not. This is a land use problem.
skepticView.interpretation: If fiat money caused housing unaffordability, it would affect all housing markets equally. Instead, the crisis is concentrated in places with restrictive zoning. Texas, a fiat-money state, has maintained housing affordability through permissive building policies.

neutralView.title: Supply constraints, wage stagnation, and monetary policy all contribute
neutralView.summary: The tripling of hours needed to buy a home reflects insufficient housing construction, stagnant real wages, and low interest rates that inflated prices.
neutralView.interpretation: This chart captures a genuinely alarming trend. A median worker now must work nearly 3x as long to buy a median home as in 1960. The causes are multi-factorial: zoning laws restrict supply, wages haven't kept pace, and low rates inflated prices. Monetary policy is one piece, but housing policy is the bigger lever.

believerView.title: Fiat money made housing unaffordable for working Americans
believerView.summary: Under the gold standard, homes cost 2-3 years of income. Fiat money's credit expansion and asset inflation pushed housing to 6+ years of income, making the American Dream impossible for many.
believerView.interpretation: The numbers are stark: 5,700 hours in 1960 versus 15,700 in 2023. The dollar lost 95% of its purchasing power since 1971, and housing prices — the largest purchase most Americans make — absorbed all of that devaluation and more. This is fiat money's most visible failure.
